thread.title: Play nice or risk regulation: BCA chief
thread.title_full: Play nice or risk regulation: BCA chief

author: Stuart Condie
title: Play nice or risk regulation: BCA chief
text:
AUSTRALIAN companies could risk being hit with onerous government regulation if they don't make efforts to ensure they behave ethically.
BUSINESS Council of Australia chief executive Jennifer Westacott says industries beyond financial services could find themselves bound by red tape in the form of regulation unless they applied ethical standards to their businesses.
The financial advice industry has been forced to undertake reform in the wake of the dodgy advice scandal that led to the big banks forking out compensation and appearing before a Senate committee. "It is important for companies to get out ahead. We do not want governments regulating this because they will always regulate the wrong thing. We know that from history," Ms Westacott said on Thursday. "It's hugely important that boards have conversations on these issues." Speaking at an Australia Israel Chamber of Commerce event in Sydney, Ms Westacott and AMP Capital managing director Stephen Dunne acknowledged it is difficult for boards to reconcile a desire to adhere to a moral code while fulfilling their ultimate responsibility to their shareholders. But Ms Westacott said most people want to be proud of their organisations. "Ultimately, organisations are people so when we talk about organisations we're talking about people. People innovate, people decide whether to act ethically," she said. Mr Dunne said only $30 billion out of $2 trillion invested in superannuation funds was centred on ethical investing, but that Australians are taking increasing notice of where their money is going. "We're only now starting to see individuals understand they're part of a system and they need to be accountable not only for themselves and not only to their firm but they need to have a broader view of the industry they are part of," he said.
